Whilome divided from the maine land stood</br>A Forrest in the circle of a flood,</br>Which was the Calidonian wood eclipt,</br>And long time there the Lion his Court kept,</br>And gave good Lawes, unto each plyant beast,</br>When bloody broyles and rigid stirres were cast,</br>For long had beene the warre and perillous </br>Betweene the Birds and Hippopotamus</br>For the Batavian Fens and Calidon</br>In the Sea-horse's cause did Armes put on</br>Against the Eagle, for great pitty 'twere</br>That weakenesse should too much oppression beare.

But letting passe this neddlesse talke, Ile tell</br>What in the Lions peacefull raigne befell.</br>He ranging in the Forrest on a day</br>Only for thirst of pastime not for pray,</br>A goodly Hart espies so faire a creature,</br>Acteon in his metamorphos'd feature</br>I weene was not, and well he knew  by heart</br>Both gracefull complement, and courtly art,</br>And due obeysance did unto his Grace,</br>Low lowting with his knees upon the grasse.</br>The Lion with a blithe and merry looke</br>His humble Subject from the ground up took,</br>And like a Prince both kinde and Debonaire,</br>Him entertained with much language faire,</br>My friend. quoth he, thou must attend on me</br>To live at Court, it best beseemeth thee,</br>If to thy outward parts suteth thy wit,</br>Needs must thy  service for a King be fit.

The beast then humbly thankt his Majestie,</br>And speaking with a gracefull modesty</br>Thus said, My Pedegree is meane, not base,</br>For I was bred, and borne, of gentle race,</br>I cannot shew a long continued line,</br>Nor boast of what I cannot claime for mine,</br>But for my service, if you please to use it,</br>Impose what charge you will, Ile not refuse it.

The Lion to be briefe, leads him to Court,</br>Where he prefer'd him soone in such a sort</br>That he who was least fearde not long since,</br>Became in power even equall with his Prince,</br>Such heapes of honours  were throwne on his back</br>As would have made the Gyants shoulders crack</br>(Which holds up heaven) long with his Lord he rested</br>In sweet content, not envy'd, nor molested;</br>He for his kindred, did great fortune finde,</br>Prefer'd the Roe, the Fallow Deere, the Hinde,</br>For what he crav'd was his, he had the art</br>Of pleasing, and had wonne his Soveraignes heart,</br>Who in a jesting manner oft would throw</br>His Royall Crowne upon his branched brow,</br>And with some favour oft would grace his home,</br>Or with some goodly Gemme his eare adorn.</br>Well knew the Hart he was hits eye-sights Jewell,</br>And to his fires still added store of fewell,</br>Oft would he to some Christall fountaine trace,</br>And therein view his guilded head and face,</br>By the direction of that watery glasse</br>There men ing what not to his likeing was,</br>Oft would he wend unto the Adders Denne,</br>Whom with his strong breath he drew forth, and then</br>Him swallowed quick, for to preserve his youth</br>Much paines he took, to keepe his soft skin smooth.</br>His breast a pillow was for his Lords head,</br>His eyes were books, whereon he daily read,</br>Like to those loving Brothers in the skie,</br>They were endu'd with equall Sympathy,</br>His blisfull smyles presented to his Lord,</br>Their passions struck a mirthfull monacord,</br>His favours object he was onely made,</br>His was the substance, all beasts else the shade,</br>Like Fraternall lights, which doe present</br>To joyfull Seamen, hope of good event,</br>So they together ranged through the groves,</br>While all besides stood wondring at their loves.</br>Sertorius that famous Roman knight,</br>Would never bring his Souldiers out to fight,</br>Till he had beene by his white Hinde advised</br>Of future haps, even so the Lion prized</br>The Counsell of this Hart, and did commit</br>All weighty Matters to his trust and wit;</br>He made him Ruler of the great greene Lake:</br>The Lyonell him for his Mate did take</br>When he to the Hesperian Forrest went,</br>For by his old Syre he was thither sent,</br>Not for a golden Apple, or a fleece</br>Of Gold, but for to Court the Eagles neece,</br>So was he blest by hap, that he came back,</br>Without a Mistris, and without a wrack.</br>The beasts at his returne did so rejoyce,</br>That Hills and Valleys sounded with the noyse.</br>The Camell danc'd, the horse for joy did wince</br>And all the Forrest eccho'd, welcome Prince;</br>The Hart for his good service done they prais'd,</br>And would have beene contented to have rais'd</br>Statues in's honour, if they had not thought</br>Idolatry thereby might in be brought.</br>Twice had not Sal past through the Zodiack,</br>Ere Leas death clad all the beasts in black.

Then with applause and hope they entertaine,</br>The brave young Lyon for their Soveraigne,</br>He bent to glorious actions did provide</br>Great forces to abate the Eagles pride,</br>Shee banding with the Dragon that doth dwell,</br>In Satans Denne neere the high way to hell,</br>(As Poets say) had wrought  such griefe and smart </br>To beasts and Fishes, even in every part.

This monstrous Dragons nature was so strange,</br>So noysome, that he needed not to range</br>About the world to passe the Alpes, or Seas,</br>To plague his wretched foes, for he at ease,</br>And lurking his filthy hole and nest,</br>Could quite  destroy, or Fish or Fowle, or beast,</br>He could infect the Aire, with his ranck breath,</br>And on each object glance, nought else but death;</br>Pure Christall streames he turnes to poyson black,</br>Where he oppos'd, all surely went to wrack.</br>Besides  he had a sort of noysome Creatures</br>At his command, which in disguised features, </br>Would search each Clime, and wont to flye by night</br>(The storie sayes) the Cockatrices height.</br>These were his damned Ministers, these caus'd</br>Great funeralls, and made all beasts amaz'd.</br>That few or none the Dragon durst contemne,</br>His strength and Malice so affrighted them.</br>Fish, fowle, and beast, be long time rul'd at-will:</br>What he requir'd, they durst not but fulfill.

He did usurp that power, which he well knew,</br>Was both the Lyons and the Eagles due.</br>But Jove that  sees, and rules all things  below,</br>Resolves to let his pride no higher grow.</br>Least like his old, snake-footed Ancestry,</br>His proud Ambition, might annoy the skie.</br>Then sends he downe his winged post to hast,</br>Who through the bright Spheares in a moment past,</br>And first in the Hircinian forrest lights,</br>Where he his message  openly recites </br>Unto the Eagle who was hitherto</br>Joves  owne deere bird, though now she be not so.</br>He told her that the Dragons power was not</br>By law obtain'd, but by oppression got,</br>That in the Forrest he no title had,</br>Of Rule or Soveraignety, but what was bad.</br>And what he had by falsehood erst obtain'd,</br>Be now with Craft and open wrong maintain'd.

The Scepter of the Forrest is (said he)</br>Thy due, (O Princely Bird) except it be,</br>Where the bold Lyon umpires, or his beast,</br>The Dragon hath no right nor interest,</br>To rule within the limits of thy woods</br>A theefe he is, and robs thee of thy goods.

Then let him be cashier'd, thrust out from hence,</br>Renounce all fealty, and obedience</br>Earst done to him, for now Jove thee commands</br>To pluck thy freedome from the Tyrants hands.</br>This said, the Eagle with a lowly nod</br>And Cringe, did doe obeysance to the God,</br>And thus beginning after a short pawse,</br>Against her selfe Maintaines the Dragons cause.

A Crowne (said she) best fits the wisest head,</br>As doth a Miter the best littered,</br>And who more prudent then the Dragon is,</br>Who more exact in Acts, and sciences?</br>He he alone keepe, all the sacred keyes,</br>Of holy and religious mysteries.

And if that strength beseemes a ruler well</br>In valour, who may be his Parallell?</br>The stoutest beast is with his noyse dismaid,</br>Yea of his wrath the Lion is affraid.</br>Therefore the Dragon best deserves to be</br>The Forrest Prince, and so shall be for me.
Hermes that could not her proud language brook</br>Longer, bewraid his anger with his looke,</br>And through disdaine to bid the Dame adue,</br>Hee tooke him to his wings, and thence he flew.

He gone the whole assembly gan to mutter,</br>And each his mind did to his fellow utter,</br>The Kite the Eagles answer did allow,</br>So did the Owls, the Ostrich and the Crow,</br>But so did not the Storke and Pelican,</br>The watchfull Crane, the Falcon, and the Swan,</br>The Beare, the Wolfe, the Boare, the Stagge, the Hind,</br>Were altogether  of the Eagles mind.</br>But the Elephant, the horse, the Unicorne,</br>Did their opinions contradict, and scorne,</br>And said, she to the Dragon did submit</br>Herselfe, for her owne proper benefit,</br>Forsooth that shee might by this power draw,</br>Her subjects into a more servile awe,</br>Or if ambition did not cause the Error,</br>It was ignoble Cowardize, and terror</br>Of his great force, who was indeed a beast,</br>Of no such strength and vigour, as she guest,</br>And as for his Religion (they say all)</br>It was but meerely Hypocriticall;</br>A faigned feature to beguile his friend,</br>A toole made by him, to worke his owne end;</br>And therefore they would never more accord,</br>To take so base a scarecrow, for their Lord,</br>This disagreements of opinion stirr'd,</br>Beast against beast, and Bird was against bird.</br>Thus in the Hircinian Forrest 'gan the strife,</br>Which mickle blood hath cost, and many a life.
But Hermes now had pli'd his wings so well,</br>That in the woods of Calidon he fell,</br>And did his messuage to the Lyon there,</br>The same which earst to th' Eagle he did beare.

The Lion and the beasts attentively</br>His Counsell heard, then with one voyce did cry,</br>The God speakes well, nor is it meet or fit</br>Said they, that we the Dragon should permit,</br>To umpire in the limits of our woods,</br>Therefore we are resolv'd to spend our bloods,</br>Our selves from his authority to free,</br>The Lion our sole Generall shall be.

Hermes reply d, the auspicious Deityes,</br>Shall second your thrice worthy enterprise,</br>And that the Princely Lion may not feare</br>The Dragons devillish spight, we give him here,</br>An herbe of force, so rare and exquisite,</br>That it doth frustrate all enchantment quite.

Most thankfully the Lion his gift tooke,</br>Expressing plaine with gesture and with looke</br>Acceptance kind, the God bids him adew,</br>And up into Joves ayrie place he flew,</br>Where to the Senate of the Gods he told,</br>How by the Eagle he had been controld.</br>And how the Calidonian Lion did</br>Resolve to doe, what his advise did bid.

And did the Eagle (quoth the Thunderer)</br>Thus sleight our message, and our messenger?</br>With that he leaning an his Ivory Rod</br>Made heaven, and Earth, and Seas at once to nod</br>By shaking of his terrifying locks,</br>And thrice his hand upon his breast he knocks.

Is all respect (said hee) now cleane forgot,</br>What damn'd ingratefull humor doth besot,</br>That rash fond foolish Bird?  did I in vaine,</br>Make her the Birds dread Queene and Soveraigne?</br>Did I so oft daine to put on her shape,</br>From Junoes watchfull eye to make escape;</br>Was her forme onely fit to make my theft,</br>When of her Ganimed, Troy bereft?</br>Did I my sacred selfe hide in a feature,</br>Of so disloyall and so vilde a creature?</br>Wert thou ( false Bird) thought worthy for to beare,</br>The fiery Weapons of the Thunderer?</br>What dare not mortalls doe, if they see mee</br>At thy contempt to winck, not punnish thee?</br>And thou O Dragon sweld with poysonous pride,</br>Whose speckled bulk nine Acres breadth doth hide,</br>Then his keene bolt with fearefull countenance,</br>He takes in hand beginning to advance</br>His everlasting fist, while all the route</br>Of Deities did quake, save Juno stoute,</br>For still the angry Gods did much repine,</br>To see the Arcadian Beares bright Nonacrine</br>And her young Sonne, to shine before her face,</br>The bright Memorialls of that great disgrace;</br>That Jove had done her bed, now is time fit,</br>Thought she, to try with wedlock breakers quit;</br>And as he hath fixt just before my face</br>My foes, I will serve him with the same sauce,</br>And ere he could let flye his dolefull dart</br>Against the Eagle, and the Dragons hart;</br>From earth she snatcht them up, (him unawares)</br>With an impetuous wind, and made them starres,</br>The Dragon she did place close by the Beares,</br>Them ever to torment with horrid feares,</br>For though they were twice chang'd, yet they injoyed</br>Their former minds, and fear'd to be destroyed,</br>By the fierce Dragons wrath, who swiftly doth,</br>Alway about the Poole pursue them both,</br>But angry Jove full of disdaine, and scorne,</br>To be thus checked, strictly enjoyn'd the morne,</br>That when he drove the heard of starrs too slack,</br>There burning heat in Amphytritis lake,</br>He should remember to fulfull his mind,</br>And leave the thirsty Dragon still behind,</br>But in remembrance of old love, he gave</br>The Eagle leave her wings in Seas to lave.

This rash act of Joves queene bred divers rumors</br>Above, the Gods according to their humors,</br>Censur'd the fact, and most did Juno blame,</br>But great despight did Joves hart so inflame,</br>That once he was  resolv'd downe from the skies,</br>Quite to Cashiere all female Deities.</br>Then wise Minerva rose up from her place.</br>With splendent lustre, and a comely grace.

Not wrath, but modesty made her looke red,</br>For those that will perswade, must not be led</br>By choller, then a low voyc'd murmur fills</br>The Court, such sound within the shallow rills,</br>Pibbles are wont to make, when they doe chide</br>The streame, because she will not faster glide.

Thus she begins, If all for ones offence</br>Must smart, then what availeth innocence?</br>If that some one hath done amisse, then shall</br>The vengeance of the crime extend to all,</br>Is this your Justice, wherein doth relye,</br>(Yee Gods) your kingdomes great eternitie?</br>Are all good turnes worne out of minde and gon,</br>What doe the Gods admit Oblivion?</br>Were Victory and I your chiefest helpe,</br>When earth sent forth her hundred pawed whelpe,</br>To throw you headlong from the battlements,</br>Did she and I alone stand at defence,</br>When ye in Niles seaven doores your selves did hide</br>In various shapes, for feare to be descride,</br>Then let us all be to the Earth confin'd</br>In hills or woods, we shall some harbours find.</br>The Nymphs shall entertaine us in some grove,</br>And old Silvanus shall be then our love</br>Such pastimes  wee shall meet with all below,</br>As all the skies the like did never show.</br>Then come along Astrea with thy traine,</br>(All faith and pitty hence) ye shall againe</br>To earth perforce, dispatch and come away</br>( O Victory!)  Juno make no delay,</br>Let Jove make merry with his Nonacrine,</br>His pretty Ganymed, and Hebe fine.

The Goddesses thus ready to depart,</br>Jove suddenly did from his throne upstart,</br>And by the sleeve disdainefull Juno snatcht,</br>But Vulcan, as he would have Pallas catcht,</br>The angry Dame, so rough a knock him wrought,</br>That unto him the mickle sorrow brought.</br>With the but-end of her launce, that the lout</br>Saw plainely then the world turnd round about.</br>But while the God with lowly blandishment,</br>To pacifie the Goddesses was bent,</br>Vulcan   brings  in a Flaggon and a Cup,</br>With lusty Nectar to the brim fild up,</br>To Juno he a bowle gives, she to Jove,</br>In wine remembers all respect and love,</br>He pledg'd her, and to Pallas dranck another,</br>She drinkes to Mars, and Mars to Cupids mother.</br>Thus like the Sheares full bowles Went round apace,</br>And Phoebus did their mirth with Musick grace,</br>While to his Harpe the Muses did apply,</br>Their voyces with a heavenly Symphonie.</br>So long they quaff'd, such was the liquors strength,</br>That soone a sleepe they cought downe all at length.</br>But now I come back, leaving them at rest,</br>Unto the Matter whence I have digrest.

Now are the Lions ships met altogether,</br>And under sayle to goe, the Lord knowes whether.</br>But first I should recount as it is meet,</br>Who were commanders in this goodly fleet.</br>Then Oh the thrice three Nymphes, that dwell upon</br>Parnassus greene, and shades of Helicon,</br>Assist me with your skill, whilst I rehearse</br>Names of those doughty wights, whom courage fearce</br>And thirst of Reputation led as far,</br>As the Herculian pillars to make war.</br>The Hart was in respect of office tide,</br>As many say, this enterprise to guide.</br>But loath the Lion was to condescend,</br>To Bruit unconstant Neptune with his friend;</br>For it had rashnesse argu'd to have let,</br>So faire a Gemme at six and seaven be set,</br>Yet some affirme that he to Sea had gone,</br>Had not the Silver Nymphes made such moane,</br>That altogether to the Lion came,</br>Beseeching him to keepe the Hart at home,</br>For to say truth, greene coole and shady bowers,</br>Soft Grassie bancks, and beds of fragrant flowers;</br>The remisse nature of the beast did please,</br>Better then hard ribb'd Ships and troubled Seas;</br>But in his roome the Mule went sole Commander,</br>A well experienc'd Knight, an ancient stander,</br>He for so great a charge was thought most fit,</br>For practice long had season'd well his wit,</br>There went the Horse for brave atchievements bred,</br>Whom false Hiennas foule adulterous bed</br>Had nigh-well slaine of yore, the Bull, the Beare,</br>The Mastiffe and the greedy Hound were there,</br>But so was not the Boare who had chang'd knocks</br>Not long before with the Iberian Fox,</br>And dy'd soone after, and with him deceas'd</br>As many feare the fortune of the beast:

Like those adventurous Gentlemen of Greece</br>To Colchos sayling for the goulden Fleece,</br>Or like those fifty Knights sworne to destory</br>For wanton Helens rape, unhappy Troy:</br>So did these Gallants glide in Neptunes brest</br>With passing pride, till all heads were possest</br>With expectation of great deeds of worth,</br>Even so the Mountaines traveld, and brought forth</br>A Mouse, they went for gold, but sure I am</br>They brought nought home worth speaking of but shame.</br>Fortune miscarried their attempts they said,</br>For had she lent them her auspicious aid,</br>Good service had beene done, but whosoere</br>Was to be blam'd, the Mule the burthen bare,</br>And through extream despaire desir'd to dye,</br>Lamenting his unhappy destiny,</br>To quench his thirst of death, himselfe he cast</br>Into the maine, where he had drunk his last,</br>If Thetis in a pittiful regard</br>The life of the poore miser had not spar'd.</br>She softly entertaines him in her wave,</br>And while he strives to make the Sea his grave</br>His featur's chang'd, and he's with feathers clad</br>And turn'd into a foule, yet still he had</br>The selfesame minde, and full of anger still</br>Because he must live, sore against his will,</br>Into the aire on high he mounted oft,</br>And on the waves himselfe throwes from aloft,</br>His feathers eas'd his fall, full oft he dives</br>Into the maine, to dye in vaine he strives.</br>Care and displeasure makes him leane and bare,</br>His neck and bill still long and slender are,</br>So are his legs, in Sea he lives alway,</br>This Foule is call'd a Gull, as Seamen say.

Much damage and more infamy lights on</br>The stout inhabitants of Calidon,</br>For this inglorious voyage and that wood</br>Which erst a terror to each Forrest flood,</br>Was now no better then a Hens neast thought,</br>Unto  so low an ebbe the beasts were brought.</br>They much perplext did to the Temple flye,</br>Imploring aide and pitty from the skie,</br>They crave a medicine for their maladies,</br>And long to finde out where the humour lyes</br>That breeds their troubles, they conclude at last</br>A sacred Messenger to send in haste</br>To Delphos by Apollos Temple grac'd,</br>Which in the middle of the Earth was plac'd</br>The Elephant was thought to be most fit</br>To take this charge, for gravity and wit</br>He to the Temple comes and humbly fals</br>Before the Altar of the God, and cals</br>For his auspicious lot with minde and voice.</br>Then suddenly was heard a hideous noise</br>Of the approaching, God, the Priest doth crie,</br>Be all prophane farre off, the God is nigh.</br>Then with deepe terror was the Pilgrim strooke,</br>The place, the Lawrell, and the Altar shook,</br>The Quiver of the God likewise did shake</br>And from the Vault a hollow voice thus spake.

When the humour which is bred</br>Ith heart, shall cease to annoy the head,</br>When Justice shall not be controld</br>By greatnesse, nor be bought nor sold,</br>When smooth'd vice shall be cast downe</br>And honour be faire Merits crowne,</br>When gleaning Patrons shall desist</br>To aske an offring of the Priest,</br>When crafty Foxes shall not pluck</br>The silly Goose, and foolish Duck,</br>When greedy Wolves shall cease to cramb</br>Their guts with blood of tender Lambe;</br>Then shall your Forrest finde reliefe,</br>And be preserv'd from feare of griefe.

The Elephant returnes, while all expect</br>And are assembled to heare the effect</br>Of his Embassage, and he doth report</br>The answer of the God, in open Court,</br>The Lion and the Hart, the Wolfe, the Beare,</br>The Bull, the Buffle, and the Elke were there,</br>The noble Unicorne was not in place</br>For he offended had the Lions grace,</br>And in his white Rock was imprisoned</br>Because the young Monoceros he did wed,</br>The Princely Leopard borne of high stem,</br>And was indeed fit to be linck'd with them.</br>But sore displeasure did the Lion fill</br>Because the Lovers sought nor his good will</br>Ere they did match, but others said the Hart</br>Unto the Unicorne bred all the smart,</br>For he thought to have matcht as most did guesse,</br>The Buck his cosen with the Leopardesse;</br>But so kinde Hymen for the Damsell stood</br>That she got one more worthy of her blood.</br>Now gan the wiser Beasts to call to minde</br>The Harts assent, his merit, and his kinde,</br>They saw him in the highest circle fixt,</br>That very little distance was betwixt</br>The Lion and his height, when he each day</br>Did feast with honour, and with honour play.</br>So did Adonis in the Paphyan Grove</br>On Rosie beds sport with the Queene of love.</br>They saw him turne about the Orbs at will,</br>Yet had this wood receiv'd no good, but ill</br>From his great inauspicious influence.</br>Thus then the Elephant began:  farre hence</br>Be all unbridled headstrong passion,</br>Let Justice, Piety, Religion,</br>Be Mynates here, great Empires within these</br>No Empires are, but mighty Theeveries.</br>And since this Court affords a remedy</br>For each abuse, and gives free liberty</br>Unto the sick weale publick to descry</br>What breeds her paine, and where the same doth lye;</br>Then let my zeale crave gentle sufferance</br>To speake for her, but ill I deeme my chance</br>That I must bring againe upon the stage,</br>Things erst done by so great a personage</br>As is the Hart, but alas tis not I,</br>It is your Countrey, and your Monarchy.

Oh mighty Lyon, they are both dismaid,</br>With scare of Dissolution, and crave aid.</br>The fierce Iberian Griffin stands before us,</br>Prest to espie advantage to devoure us,</br>And mischiefe, malice, warre, about him skip,</br>He threats the sword, the rope, the yoke, the whip;</br>Our weaknesse makes him strong, our cowardize</br>Doth promise fortune to his enterprize;</br>And yonder doth the Eagle prey upon</br>Our overmatcht Allyes, while we look on,</br>And friendly Rhyne, low in his channell lyes,</br>And to his Rills in vaine for succor cries.</br>For burnt fac'd ruine hath Carrous'd them up</br>With Healths to Dissolution in a cup,</br>Compos'd of ashes, rubbish, dust, and stone,</br>The hideous worke of dire confusion.</br>And at our Elbow stands the Crocodile</br>Masking his rancour with a feined smile.</br>He animiates us to begin the warre,</br>But malice is a divellish counsellor.</br>Behold yon green ey'd Lake, whose gentle flood</br>With kind imbraces clip, and hug our wood,</br>And stand like wals by Jove and Neptune fixt</br>Our cruell enemies, and us betwixt.</br>Our enemies have wonne those wals, how can</br>The Towne hold out when all the wals are tane</br>Not long since were we Lords of Sea and Land</br>Durst breath in any aire, tread any sand</br>Our Spartanes vertues, and Herculian vigour</br>Releiv'd the weak puld downe the oppressors rigour,</br>But now alas things have put on new shapes,</br>Our Forrest is become a Denne of Apes.</br>The greedy Ostridge, and the obscene Owle</br>Do Tymber in our woods and Satyrs foule</br>Frequent our thickets, vertue is divorc'd,</br>From greatnesse, Natures excellence is forc'd</br>By appetite, and reason is defloured</br>By vile affections, Arts are now devoured</br>By great panch'd ignorance, fidelity,</br>Consists in Lucre, and in Luxury.</br>Our Forrest is a field of naughtinesse,</br>Or rather like foule Lernas marrishnesse,</br>Where sinne doth lurke, crested with many crimes</br>Like Hidra, oh Alcides, helpe betimes,</br>Helpe mighty Prince, and banish all delay,</br>Meet the approaching ill, and take away</br>Pernicious causes, nor do we envie</br>Against thy judgement, Royall Majestie</br>That thou thy Hart in so high place dost hold</br>Princes affections must not be controld</br>By subjects humours, for there love may flye</br>Or high or low, none ought to ask them why</br>To rule, and not to serve Kings were ordain'd,</br>They may be oft advis'd but neare constraind.</br>Yea though the State through their ill government</br>Be sure to fall, Subjects must be content.

But as the lawes of God and man oblige</br>Subjects unto their Soveraigne Lord and Liege,</br>So doth the lawes of God alone binde Kings,</br>With  equity to steere the course of things.</br>But if they shall neglect their charge and cure,</br>None  must for reformation put in ure</br>Any sinister course, for they alone</br>To God must give account what they have done,</br>But as all force is divelish and prophane</br>By vassals 'gainst their Princes undertane,</br>So wholesome counsell is a soveraigne way</br>To worke with them, in some respects though they</br>Be Gods, yet like men do they understand,</br>So die they shall, though they like Gods command.

Whilome (dread Soveraigne) was the Hares good grace,</br>As high in peoples favour, as in place,</br>But things growne to their height needs must we see</br>Decline, the very Starres unstable be;</br>No sooner Sol begins to rise then fall,</br>The infant that begins to live, withall</br>Begins to dye; yet still might'st thou have stood</br>Untoucht, O Hart, hadst thou been still as good:</br>As great, more would the Elephant have spake,</br>But night came on, and the assemblies brake.

Henceforth against the Hart gan many rise</br>Accusing him of great enormities,</br>Light fame, as quick of bearing as of flight,</br>That seldome doth befriend a favorite,</br>Soone heares the accusation of the Hart,</br>And in a thousand scrols writes every part,</br>And as if matters were not ill enough,</br>She addeth something still of her owne stuffe,</br>With these same scrols she fil'd her wide mouthd scrip</br>And with her wings the buxome sire doth clip,</br>And as the flew the Forrest round about,</br>Whole handfuls of her scrols she casteth out,</br>So doth Septembers carefull seedsman throw</br>The  kirnels plumbe before the crooked plough;</br>Such bitter libels did this tattler spread,</br>That heartily all wisht, the Hart were dead,</br>So high the fury of the beasts were growne</br>That sore the Hart began to feare the Crowne,</br>Therefore to shunne each dirie accident,</br>He to the house of Politea went</br>To crave her counsell in so hard a case;</br>Lowe in the gloomie vale her Pallace</br>Was Hewne From a Marble Rock by Mulciber</br>The craftsman of the Gods, she dwelleth there</br>Secur'd from danger of damn'd treacherie</br>Who once to undermine her house did try,</br>Thinking to have blowne her up into the skies</br>As doth the Giant which in Etna lyes,</br>Spew flaming stones, no thorow-faire is there,</br>No Hermits Cell, no shepherds Cottage neere,</br>No beasts do graze upon the neighbour hils,</br>No chirping birds the cliffes with ecchos fils;</br>Black sollitude there alwayes walkes the round</br>With foulded armes and eyes bent to the ground.</br>Upon the top of all the house was rear'd</br>A Tower, which so exceeding high appear'd,</br>That it Ixion-like did seeme to kisse</br>The clouds, on top of which there seated is</br>One called providence, who holds a glasse</br>Wherewith she sees what's done in every place</br>Beneath the Cope, with this she doth espie</br>The drifts of Kings, and hidden plots descrie,</br>A huge high wall was built about the place</br>In which not any port or entrance was</br>Except one private posterne, which was kept</br>By a grave Sire whose secrecy was clept.</br>The Hart comes to the doore and safely knocks,</br>The watchfull Porter with long snowie locks</br>And beard, soon heard the sound, and soon drew neer,</br>But ere he did unlock, askt who was there,</br>A friend quoth the Hart, then he enquir'd his name,</br>What was his errand and from whence he came,</br>With such wise answers, did the Hart him win,</br>That he unlockt the gate, and let him in;</br>Then did a goodly groome discretion height,</br>To Paliteas Hall conduct him right,</br>Where on such uncouth shapes of things he gaz'd,</br>That like a Statue he stood still amazd.</br>Upon an arch sat Politea high,</br>With many Dames in seemely order by.</br>And though she and the Ladies seemd to be,</br>As jolly Dames as eyes could wish to see,</br>Yet she alas was changd in face and grace,</br>Ere since the faire Astrea lost her place</br>And most part of her traine, that sate hereby</br>Were but meere shades made to delude the eye,</br>But fierce ambition beaten and repeld</br>From her attempt in the Phlegrean field</br>Where she was hunting them, earths gracelesse fries</br>To mount on Mountaines, and to climbe the skies,</br>Yet still retaind her former spight and hate,</br>Although the blow did much her strength abate,</br>But having provd the prowesse  of the Gods</br>And to her cost and sorrow seene the odds,</br>She would no more in armes against them go,</br>But meane to single out a weaker foe</br>Great Politea that renowned Queene</br>Was she on whom she vowd to wreck her teene,</br>But laying steely armes and shield aside</br>Another way to work her ends she tryd;</br>She by a treaty thought to get more gaine</br>Then ere by open force she could attaine,</br>A beautious Lady in her traine she hid</br>Which high desire her all in white she clad</br>And with an Olive wreath she dight her head,</br>And in her hand she likewise carried</br>An Olive branch, a hundred Maids of honour</br>(With Olive likewise crownd) did waight upon her,</br>Though these like messengers of peace were clad</br>Yet warre and murther in their hearts they had,</br>For they were all begirt with faulchions keene,</br>Which underneath their vestures were not seene,</br>She these instructs with wondrous subtilties,</br>Under pretence of Friendship to surprise</br>Queene Politeas fort, but when she came</br>Neere to the place, they sent a crafty Dame,</br>Before unto the Castle, to obtaine amaine,</br>A safe conduct for desire, and her traine.</br>This speedy Herald delectation height,</br>As faire a creature to the outward sight,</br>As ever eye beheld, and yet was shee</br>As foule deform'd a monster as could be,</br>Besides her outward grace she had a tongue,</br>Most skillfull to perswade, and passing strong;</br>Shee having entred Politeas Hall,</br>Where then was sitting mongst her Ladies all</br>Betweene Religion, and Astrea faire,</br>So wittily her messuage did declare,</br>That Politea gave her free consent,</br>That foule desire and all her Rabblement,</br>Might come into the fortresse, all in vaine</br>Astrea and her fellowes did complaine;</br>And like Liceas priests with flaring haire,</br>With out-cryes shrill, they rent the tender ayre.

Trust not ambitious friendly shewes they cried,</br>Trust not  desire, let accesse be denied,</br>And like Troyes unbeleeved Prophesies,</br>They did presage approaching miseries,</br>In vaine they told of dangers that were neere,</br>For Politea would not lend an Eare.</br>Then fraught with griefe, and deepe disdaine they flew</br>From thence to heaven, and bid the earth adiew;</br>Thus Politea was quite left alone, Religion,</br>Justice, Temperance were gone,</br>Faith, Pitty, Fortitude, were flowne away,</br>None of Astreas traine behind would stay,</br>But hope, for she bewailing the weake state</br>Of wretched men slunck close by out at gate,</br>And to the wide world did betake her selfe,</br>A profest foe to that most damned elfe;</br>Which height despaire, she gives men much reliefe</br>That be in paine, Calamitie and griefe,</br>Now is despaire at Politeas Fort,</br>Safely arriv'd and entring the Court.</br>A Dame that kept the Tower of consent,</br>The keyes thereof did unto her present;</br>Then on she went into the Hall apace</br>Where Politea, at her feete crav'd grace,</br>Which she obteyned, but one this Condition</br>Forsooth, that she forthwith yeeld to Ambition</br>All Homage, fealtie, and Obedience,</br>And alwayes hold her for her liege and Prince;</br>To keepe these Covenants she was bound by oath,</br>So she her honour lost and freedome both;</br>Then Superstition, false-hood thirst of gaine,</br>Succeeded faire Astrea and her traine,</br>Yea bloudy Murther, and foule treachery,</br>Then streight crept closely in and there stood by,</br>And though the Hart saw them he could not spie,</br>Their ugly shapes and great deformity;</br>For they were clad in vertues faire array,</br>Which she had left in haste to flye away,</br>Their faces sprent, were with a tincture vile,</br>Made of the ordure of a Crocodile,</br>And Dragons milke, love did Medea move,</br>To use this Ceruse, first for Jasons love;</br>But the Hart viewed with most intention,</br>The workemanship and rare Invention;</br>That there on every side was to be seene,</br>Where many Statues were of famous men,</br>High in the roofe, which dust well nigh defac'd,</br>Where Numa, Solon, and Lycurgus plac'd,</br>And many other did stand them beside,</br>Which time had made unfit to be descri'd,</br>Each politicians plot was there display'd,</br>From point to point, as it at first was laid;</br>The Pope was pictur'd there, and Charles the great</br>Each helping other, to Atchieve his feat.</br>Charles for the Empire of the West did try</br>His skill the Pope for his Supremacie:</br>Pope Hildebrands foule plots were there exprest,</br>Against the Luthers Empire of the West,</br>Pope Alexander and his wicked Sonne,</br>Duke Valentine, Machivells paragon</br>Were figured there, with their damned subtilty,</br>To get the Soveraignetie of Italie,</br>And Machivell was likewise to be seene</br>There with the proud D. Alva and the Scottish Queen,</br>And so was Barnevelt, who had of late,</br>A Traytor beene to the Netherlanders state,</br>Besides were portray'd amonst all these,</br>Don Spinola the warlike Genoavyes,</br>And Gondamor, two old ill-looking Scots,</br>Who both did seeme to be contriving plots,</br>To make their Mr. Westerne Emperor,</br>Full fast they ply'd their worke and labour sore,</br>All formes of State likewise that ever were,</br>Were to the eye plainly descryed there,</br>Firme Monarchies and Aristocracies,</br>Oligarchies, and worse Democrasies.

The Hart delivered from astonishment,</br>Before the Throne of Poletea went,</br>And falling on his knees did her intreat,</br>To stand his friend and teach him some good feat,</br>The fury of his foes to turne away,</br>Who had indented to worke his decay.

The Dame replies, our greatest pleasure is,</br>To succor those that are in deepe distresse,</br>Therefore we pitty thee, for thee tis good,</br>To be Commander of the Silver flood,</br>Which Cantaber is cleeped, where doe dwell</br>The learned Syrens, which strange things can tell,</br>And then be safe, let Justice worke her worst,</br>And with displeasure her owne bowells burst.

The Hart from this advise much comfort had,</br>And to the Forrest returnd blith and glad,</br>Where he reported to the Lions grace,</br>(For in his favour still he had a place)</br>The manner of his voyage, and successe,</br>And how the Goddesse taught him to redresse</br>His griefes; Him he besought to stand his friend,</br>Whereby his aimes might hit their wished end.</br>Then did he send a trusty Messenger,</br>To the inhabitants of Cantaber,</br>The Lion likewise for him intercedes,</br>By Messengers unto the Reverend heads,</br>For our of Sixteene heads issued the flood</br>Devoid of ragged Mosse and filthy Mud,</br>He tumbled on a Sandy bed full cleare,</br>Where under Peasant, might not approach neare.</br>But on his grassie bancks with Lawrell Crown'd,</br>The Nymphes and Fayries sat in circle round,</br>Composing wreathes of never dying Bayse,</br>To deck those heads, whose knowledge merits  praise.

But in this sixteene-headed spring did sit,</br>So many Syrens grave in yeares and wit,</br>These by a higher power, were put in trust</br>To order things, and keepe all right and just;</br>But one above them all was placed high</br>In honour, and in grave authority,</br>Which height Learn'd Panace a Lady fine,</br>And farre renown'd for skill and medicine;</br>But Dinamene had the second place,</br>A Dame of Comely countenance and grace.</br>Yet were her Oseants stain'd with lustfull flame,</br>From Tyneas she had an evill name,</br>She often wont to leave the Christall floods,</br>And seeke her lovely stripling in the woods,</br>Glytephone, and faire Philacreete,</br>Armold, and sage Philurope,</br>Eusibia, Panope, and Encrate.</br>Themisty, just and wise Polime,</br>Patient Cymodece, that could assawge</br>The surging Seas, when they began to rage,</br>Kind Elimuce and Antonene,</br>Faithfull Memphee, and old Zione.

All these the Daughters were of mighty Jove,</br>Begot by him in the adjoyning Grove,</br>An Academie faire, the elder daughter</br>Of Cronus and Minerva, for long after</br>Minerva bare another lively Dame,</br>Begotten of Cronus on the bancks of Thame.</br>Besides the sixteene Syrens faire, which were</br>Chiefe in the flood, three thousand moe were there,</br>Begot all by Phoebus, and great Jove,</br>Nurst and brought up all by their neighbour grove.

The Harts swift post comes to the gentle River,</br>Where he his maisters letter did deliver,</br>Unto the Syrens, who as it fell out</br>Were in their sacred bowers met about</br>Some great affaires, nor did the Messenger</br>Forget with gentle language to prefer</br>His masters humble suit, and thus he said,</br>Loe he that long hath the great Ocean swaid,</br>Who to the Fritians doth prescribe a law,</br>And keepes Eolus blustring Sonnes in awe,</br>Even he the Empire of your flood stands for,</br>Desires to be your Lord and Governour.</br>And what the Lion might command, he now</br>Requesteth, so his mildnesse doth him bow;</br>Refuse not then the Hart, who is so kind</br>For your good Lord; since tis your Soveraignes mind.

This said, the Syrens did his absence crave,</br>And told him soone, he should an answer have.</br>Then first gan Panace her selfe to advance,</br>Striking the assembly with an Austere glance,</br>Two things (said she) invites us to deny </br>The Harts request:  First doth the peoples cry</br>Deeme him unworthy of so great a place,</br>And secondly his weake and wretched case,</br>Makes him unfit to oversee our flood</br>Least he should faile at need to doe us good;</br>But on the other side his Princes love,</br>To  take him for our Ruler doth us move,</br>Tyme is a salve for many soares, but hate</br>Of Kings displeasure no time did ere abate,</br>Should we adore the rising sunne, or when</br>Hees at the hight, fall downe before him, then</br>We might be deem'd by some misdeeming Syres,</br>To be no better then vile Flatterers;</br>But doubtlesse him in his designe to prop,</br>When he is like into the deepe to drop,</br>It is an action that deserveth best,</br>The favour of the Gods, then his request</br>(And our dread Soveraignes will,) ye shall allow,</br>If my perswasion may availe with you;</br>I oft have heard well taught experience sing,</br>Tis greatest wisdome, for to please a King.

This said, a confus'd rumor the house fill'd,</br>But Pyamene his opinion held;</br>And so did many more grave headed wights,</br>Some feare, and thirst of honour some invites</br>To make the Hare their Lord, but one true blade,</br>Whom Tytan had of better mettall made,</br>Did stoutly stand against gray-headed wit,</br>Most voyces yet at length, miscarryed it,</br>But though the Hart obtained this great place,</br>The silly beasts still hated his good Grace.

Then he the Camell made of his great kin,</br>Who likewise was growne mighty by great sin,</br>For he was not to Lordly Manners borne.</br>But fortune honoured him with plenties horne,</br>For ranging in the Forrest on a day,</br>By accident he found a goodly prey.</br>A Lady  faire was on a greene banck laid,</br>Her Limbes in Carelesse posture all displaid,</br>Which under a thin vaile were halfe descri'd,</br>In emptie clouds so Phebe wont to hide</br>Her bashfull face, when she was gaz'd upon,</br>With a fixt eye, by her Endymion;</br>Certes she was one of Dianas dames,</br>Whom a long chase, and bright Apolloes flames,</br>Had from the plaines into the coole shade sent,</br>For sweet repose and gentle solacement;</br>The Camell, such was his most happy lot,</br>Did find her sleeping, and so neare her got,</br>That he lost not his opportunity,</br>But so prevail'd that he with her did lie,</br>Lewd Priapus went often in such guise,</br>Some light heel'd Nymphes in Court for to surprise.</br>The Camell lying with the Lady gate</br>Great store of money, and a great estate,</br>Her name was Thesenia the fortunate,</br>Her prateing Lovers shee went to elate</br>To high degrees, hard was my destiny,</br>Cause with that lasse, I found not grace to lie</br>Who makes her lovers rich and happy too,</br>And yeelds to each that hath a face to wooe.

The Camell lying with this Strumpet grew,</br>Worthy to weare a goodly gowne of blew,</br>How doth that giglet fortune favour fooles</br>For he was neither well train'd up in Schooles,</br>Nor ever could he of a fine wit vaunt</br>But he was passing bold and ignorant,</br>Yet expert was he in his facultie.</br>Oh what an easie Art is knavery!</br>Thus doe great knaves become great men alone,</br>Whilst true Nobility is trod upon;</br>The Scholler spends his wit, and none regards him,</br>The Souldier spends his blood, and none rewards him</br>The vertuous Gentleman, whom competence</br>Protects from want, and pinching Indigence,</br>May live at home in meane and honest port,</br>Neere looking for preferment at the Court.

Now was the Camell with great office grac'd,</br>And high in awefull seat of Honor plac'd,</br>With lookes and words the Stygian Frogs did check,</br>Who went to cry Coax breck Ekex neck,</br>Foure times a yeare in that great Hall, from whence,</br>Astrea fled away three ages since,</br>Nere was it knowne before, that Justice did</br>Depend on Hymen, or waite on a Bride,</br>She did not Nuptials know nor what was meant</br>By Venus sport of Junos blandishment,</br>She is a Queene by birth, but made a slave,</br>Damn'd be those heads that did her thus deprave.</br>Thus at length with the Camell the Hart tied</br>Bonds of Alliance, to make a stronger side;</br>And then he cals from the Cimerian land</br>The reverend Asse, and he must keepe a stand,</br>And be the buckler to a masse of sinne,</br>Whom doth not sacred thirst of money winne?</br>That faire Panara, daughter of the gods,</br>That Mistris of delight, fairer by ods</br>Then honesty, who dares not once be seene</br>When she appeares, so doth nights pale-fac'd Queen</br>Give place to Sol:  but still the beasts sore hate</br>The fearefull Hart; Jove doth commiserate</br>The Forrests state, and him from thence did take</br>Whom he had made a starre for Venus sake,</br>Whose Priest he was, if Atlas had not cri'd</br>That Heaven would from his feeble shoulders slide</br>Were he fixt there (so heavie mischiefe is)</br>But Jove to make a Metamorphosis</br>Him turn'd into an Ignis fatuus,</br>A wandring light which oft appeares to us</br>Poore swaines, that watch our flocks upon the plains,</br>This fire oft-times the timerous Clowne constraines</br>To runne through bush and brier, ditch and dale</br>For very feare, and many a diry tale</br>Is told by Peasants in the winter night</br>To maids by the fire side of the same sprite,</br>Yet fame reports (but fame tels many lyes)</br>That Jove did take the Hart up to the skies,</br>And made him a bright starre, and plac'd him neere</br>Shag-hairy Orgon the fierce Forrester,</br>Who with his staring lookes and glittering brand</br>A terror dire doth nere to him standun.</br>For the Hart (as it should seeme) and many write</br>No swordsman was, but a meere Carpet-Knight</br>Certes his stars portend (as wise men guesse)</br>Much ill to those which Art and Armes possesse,</br>And great  impoverishment to Mariners,</br>Whom it arising from the Sea deters.</br>
